content: In Joy of Cats, they define the concept of a source and the concept of a U-initial source, where U is a "forgetful" functor. I was wondering if this concept can be phrased as a universal mapping property (or as an initial object in some category).

It is written a bit after the definition of GGG-initial sources (in 10.58, but I know some copies have different numberings), that when G=UG = UG=U is the forgetful functor for some concrete category, then the UUU-initial sources are the same thing as initial sources defined in 10.41. Then in 10.42, they say that initial 1-sources are the same thing as initial morphisms defined in 8.6. In that definition there is a footnote saying [my editorialization] that the terminology for initial morphisms does not come from an obvious way to see them as initial objects in some category.

This does not answer your question but it points towards an easier angle, can we find a way to see initial morphisms as initial objects of some category. Let me reproduce the definition of initial morphism because I don't think it is well-known and it will save other readers a trip to their copy of the book.

Definition: In a category A\mathbf{A}A concrete over X\mathbf{X}X with forgetful functor UUU, a morphism f∈HomA(A,B)f \in \mathrm{Hom}_{\mathbf{A}}(A,B)f∈HomA​(A,B) is an initial morphism provided that for every object C∈Ob(A)C \in \mathrm{Ob}(\mathbf{A})C∈Ob(A) and morphism g∈HomX(UC,UA)g \in \mathrm{Hom}_{\mathbf{X}}(UC,UA)g∈HomX​(UC,UA), if Uf∘gUf \circ gUf∘g is in the image of HomA(C,B)\mathrm{Hom}_{\mathbf{A}}(C,B)HomA​(C,B) under UUU then ggg is in the image of HomA(C,A)\mathrm{Hom}_{\mathbf{A}}(C,A)HomA​(C,A) under UUU.

To get more intuition, my favorite examples are in concrete categories over Set\mathbf{Set}Set:

  • In the category of posets, the initial morphisms are functions that are order-embeddings, i.e. a≤b⇔f(a)≤f(b)a \leq b \Leftrightarrow f(a) \leq f(b)a≤b⇔f(a)≤f(b) (which forces injectivity, but that is not the important part for initial morphisms).
  • In the category of metric spaces and nonexpansive maps, the initial morphisms are isometries (i.e. d(a,b)=d(f(a),f(b))d(a,b) = d(f(a),f(b))d(a,b)=d(f(a),f(b)) (same remark for injectivity).

Informally, an initial morphism (for concrete categories over Set\mathbf{Set}Set) is a function fff that preserves properties such that when you precompose it with any function ggg, the result preserves properties if and only if ggg preserves properties.
I think most people call that a [[cartesian morphism]] (for a faithful functor).

I guess Lemma 3.1 in that page is a justification for that name, but I think there are typos. I can fix these and add a reference to the Joy of Cats. In the Related Pages, they say cartesian morphisms are precisely initial lifts of a singleton structured cosink. Am I right in saying it should be strictly initial lifts?

I suspect that the original justification of the name is that the cartesian arrows in the [[codomain fibration]] are the pullback squares, a.k.a. "cartesian squares", but I don't know for sure. I wouldn't argue that it's a particularly good name, but it's very standard and other attempts to change it have mostly fizzled.
And with definitions as given at [[final lift]], I believe a cartesian morphism should be a strictly final lift of a singleton sink.

There's a definition of U-initial source that I found in the paper Topological Categories by Brümmer that looks almost like a universal mapping property:

Let (A,U)(A, U)(A,U) be concrete. A source (fi:X→Xi)I(f_i : X \to X_i)_I(fi​:X→Xi​)I​ in AAA is UUU-initial if for every other source (gi:Y→Xi)I(g_i : Y \to X_i)_I(gi​:Y→Xi​)I​ and every h:UY→UXh : UY \to UXh:UY→UX satisfying ∀i. Ufi∘h=Ugi\forall i.\ Uf_i \circ h = Ug_i∀i. Ufi​∘h=Ugi​, there exists a unique h′:Y→Xh' : Y \to Xh′:Y→X such that Uh′=hUh' = hUh′=h and ∀i. fi∘h′=gi\forall i.\ f_i \circ h' = g_i∀i. fi​∘h′=gi​.

I have no clue how to consolidate the stuff about hhh in this definition to make it into a genuine universal mapping property though.
Looks like a universal mapping property to me. What is your definition of "genuine universal mapping property"?

Mike Shulman said:

And with definitions as given at [[final lift]], I believe a cartesian morphism should be a strictly final lift of a singleton sink.

I don't think so. Now I think it should be a strictly final lift of a singleton cosink.

If you slightly alter the definition I quoted, you get the universal mapping property of a product:

A source (fi:X→Xi)I(f_i : X \to X_i)_I(fi​:X→Xi​)I​ is a product if for every other source (gi:Y→Xi)I(g_i : Y \to X_i)_I(gi​:Y→Xi​)I​, there exists a unique h′:Y→Xh' : Y \to Xh′:Y→X such that ∀i. fi∘h′=gi\forall i.\ f_i \circ h' = g_i∀i. fi​∘h′=gi​.

Here is an attempt at making it fit my intuition for genuine universal mapping property. I will do it for III being a singleton for simplicity.

Let (A,U)(\mathbf{A},U)(A,U) be concrete and f:A→Bf: A \to Bf:A→B a morphism in A\mathbf{A}A (also called a singleton source). We define the category of lifts of fff as follows.

  • Objects are pairs of morphisms g:UC→UAg: UC \to UAg:UC→UA and h:C→Bh: C \to Bh:C→B such that Uf∘g=UhUf \circ g = UhUf∘g=Uh. Since UUU is faithful, we can also say an object is a morphism g:UC→UAg: UC \to UAg:UC→UA such that there exists h:C→Bh: C \to Bh:C→B satisfying Uf∘g=hUf \circ g = hUf∘g=h.
  • Morphisms between g:UC→UAg:UC \to UAg:UC→UA and g′:UC′→UAg': UC' \to UAg′:UC′→UA are morphisms m:C→C′m: C \to C'm:C→C′ such that h′∘m=hh' \circ m = hh′∘m=h and g′∘Um=gg' \circ Um = gg′∘Um=g.

Now, for any singleton source f:A→Bf: A \to Bf:A→B, idUA:UA→UA\mathrm{id}_{UA} : UA \to UAidUA​:UA→UA is in the category of lifts because there exists h=fh = fh=f such that Uf∘idUA=UhUf \circ \mathrm{id}_{UA} = UhUf∘idUA​=Uh. A singleton source f:A→Bf: A \to Bf:A→B is UUU-initial if and only if idUA\mathrm{id}_{UA}idUA​ is final in the category of lifts. Let me unroll the two sides to make it clear why they are equivalent:

  • fff is UUU-initial means for every g:UC→UAg: UC \to UAg:UC→UA such that there is h:C→Bh: C \to Bh:C→B satisfying Uh=Uf∘gUh = Uf \circ gUh=Uf∘g, there exists a unique gˉ:C→A\bar{g}: C \to Agˉ​:C→A such that h=f∘gˉh = f \circ \bar{g}h=f∘gˉ​ and Ugˉ=gU\bar{g} = gUgˉ​=g (Definition 10.57 in Joy of Cats).
  • idUA\mathrm{id}_{UA}idUA​ is final in the category of lifts means that for every object in that category, i.e. g:UC→UAg: UC \to UAg:UC→UA such that there is h:C→Bh: C \to Bh:C→B satisfying Uh=Uf∘gUh = Uf \circ gUh=Uf∘g, there exists a unique morphism from ggg to idUA\mathrm{id}_{UA}idUA​, that is a unique morphism gˉ:C→A\bar{g}: C \to Agˉ​:C→A such that $$f \circ \bar{g} = h$ and idUA∘Ugˉ=g\mathrm{id}_{UA} \circ U\bar{g} = gidUA​∘Ugˉ​=g or equivalently Ugˉ=gU\bar{g} = gUgˉ​=g.

@Ralph Sarkis I think that works quite well. I already had the suspicion that being "U-initial" is actually a "final" concept rather than an "initial" concept. Thanks a lot.

Ralph Sarkis said:

Now I think it should be a strictly final lift of a singleton cosink.

Yes, you're right.
Does JoC really call this notion "UUU-initial"?? As you say, it's clearly a "final" concept, not an initial one.

That's what I am thinking. In the definition of initial morphism which is what the nlab (and according to you most people) call cartesian morphism, they have this footnote:
image.png
image.png
To be honest, the way their definition is stated obfuscates the universality to me.
Ah, I guess their terminology comes from initial topology, which probably predates "initial object".
That's hugely unfortunate.

That is very confusing. I wonder how the terminology originated. Maybe it is related to the fact that the ordering of topologies on a fixed set X by inclusion (as subsets of the power set of X) is opposite to the category of topological spaces with underlying set X?

Seems possible. In any case, it would probably be better to avoid the "initial/final" terminology for liftings entirely in the future. What about generalizing the terminology of cartesian arrows and talking about "cartesian cosinks" and "opcartesian sinks"?

Yes, I think this terminology comes from to the usual subset ordering on topologies. The way I rationalize this terminology is like this: "initial" means we are talking about sources and initial objects are like sources since they have arrows coming out of it to all other objects.
